lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Props drilling is a concept in React where you pass data from one component to another through multiple intermediary components.

Let's dive into how intermediate components can act as "pass-through" layers.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
As we know, props in React are used to pass data to components.

Make sure to pick message, followed by =, and finally "Welcome to the Matrix".

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The child component can access and use the passed data through its props object.

Make sure to pick props followed by props and then ., message.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, we can not only pass data between components but also forward received props to another component.

To do that, we access the desired property from props and pass it to the next component as a new prop.

Make sure to pick props followed by message and then =, props, .message.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We don't have to pass the received property along with the same name.

Change the name of the property that we pass to the Grandchild component to content.

Make sure to pick props, followed by content, and finally props.message.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
The component receiving a property doesn't know about the previous name. It only cares about the name the property has when passed to it.

Access the passed property content.

Make sure to pick props, followed by ., and finally content.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
A received property can be passed to multiple other components.

Make sure to pick props followed by props and then ., message, props, ., message.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass the received props to the next component.

Make sure to pick props followed by props and then ., welcomeMessage.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these is a correct way to pass the prop greeting from Parent to Grandchild?

Pass received props along to GrandchildOmit props in ChildPass props directly in ParentUse state instead of props

Pass received props along to Grandchild.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Change prop names between components.

Make sure to pick cityMessage, followed by props, and finally .message.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can you modify the prop warning to alertMessage when passing it?

Use alertMessage={props.warning}Use alert={props.warning}Pass it unchangedDeclare a state for alertMessage

Use alertMessage={props.warning}.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass a prop to multiple components.

Make sure to pick quote followed by props.quote and then quote, props.quote.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: In React, we can not only accept and pass props but also manipulate them or pass multiple props to components.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When a component receives a property, it can do whatever it wants with that property.

Multiply the passed property price with 0.8 to get the discounted price. Pass the discounted price to the PriceDisplay component.

Make sure to pick discountedPrice followed by props.price and then * 0.8, discountedPrice, discountedPrice.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can make the ProductDetails component even more flexible by providing the discount as property as well instead of hardcoding to 80%.

Pass 100 as the price and 0.8 as the discount.

Make sure to pick price followed by 100 and then discount, 0.8.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the ProductDetails component, we can use the passed props to calculate the new discounted price.

The ProductDetails page accepts two properties, uses them to calculate a new price, and passes it to a child component that can render it.

Make sure to pick discountedPrice, followed by props.price, and finally props.discount.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When working with multiple components and multiple props, we can get creative.

How about creating a dedicated component for the old price that automatically applies a strikethrough to the displayed price?

Make sure to pick <OldPriceDisplay> followed by { and then props.orginalPrice, }, </OldPriceDisplay>.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Modify the price before passing it as a prop to the PriceDisplay component.

Make sure to type props.price.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following statements is true about modifying props before passing them to a component in React?

Props can be modified before passing to allow for more dynamic componentsProps must never be modified before passingModifying props causes an errorProps should only be modified within the component, not before

Props can be modified before passing to allow for more dynamic components.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component that modifies the prop before rendering it inside a header.

Make sure to pick message, followed by message.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the output of the following modified component?

Hello, CAPTAIN MARVELHello, Captain MarvelError: name is undefinedHello,

Hello, CAPTAIN MARVEL.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component that modifies movie title to uppercase before displaying along with its release year.

Make sure to pick title, followed by title.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is it beneficial to modify props before passing them along in React?

Modifying props allows more complex data manipulations before renderingModifying props reduces component reusabilityProps should only be used as they are without modificationsModified props cause an additional render

Modifying props allows more complex data manipulations before rendering.
